Annotated by Fu Dongzhen.

The Lord Lao says: The Northern Apex suspends its celestial image, and all stars pay homage to it. The Northern Apex is the Northern Thearch; the Emperor Star within the Dipper serves as the stellar sovereign, presiding in solemn dignity over the celestial patterns. As the *Analects* states: "Like the Northern Apex, it abides in its place, and all stars pay homage to it." One variant reads "the Northern Apex above," which is incorrect.

It is the pivot of creation and transformation. The Dipper’s handle and pole occupy the Thearch’s abode, governing the revolutions of the four seasons and overseeing the transformations of generation and completion. In the first, second, and third months, the Dipper’s handle points to the positions of *yin*, *mao*, and *chen*, generating and transforming the myriad things. In the fourth, fifth, and sixth months, it points to *si*, *wu*, and *wei*, nurturing and fostering the myriad things. In the seventh, eighth, and ninth months, it points to *shen*, *you*, and *xu*, ripening and maturing the myriad things. In the tenth, eleventh, and twelfth months, it points to *hai*, *zi*, and *chou*, gathering and storing the myriad things. If the Dipper’s handle does not revolve, the four seasons lose their rhythm, the Five Phases fail to respond, cold and heat deviate from their measures, yin and yang fall out of harmony, and the myriad things cannot reach completion. Thus, it is the pivot of creation and transformation.

It serves as the sovereign of human spirits, proclaiming its majesty across the Three Realms and governing the myriad numina. The Dipper is the lord of human spirits, issuing its commands and governing the myriad numina within the Three Realms. One variant reads "proclaiming majesty through statutes and precepts," which is incorrect.

It determines the appointed times of good and evil for humanity. There are those in the world who devote themselves to good deeds yet suffer many calamities—this is because their merit in goodness is not yet sufficient. Once their merit is complete, great fortune will arrive. There are those who commit evil deeds yet enjoy fortune—this is because their evil is not yet full. Once their evil is complete, great misfortune will befall them. The reason good and evil each have their appointed times is that the Supreme possesses the virtue of cherishing life. For those who do good, it awaits the fullness of their great goodness; for those who do evil, it awaits their repentance. Thus, the appointed times of good and evil become clear. If one initially pursues goodness but, due to demonic obstacles, later awakens to repentance, their merit in goodness diminishes daily while their name is added to the ledger of evil. If one begins with minor evils and, seeing no misfortune, grows accustomed to them, their sins gradually increase while their name is erased from the ledger of good. Therefore, one must not fail to guard against minor evils, nor neglect minor acts of goodness. Do not fear correcting mistakes; correction must be swift. The heart of repentance should arise within the allotted time. If one exceeds the limit, death will draw near, and even after ten thousand kalpas and a thousand rebirths, though one may repent, what can be recovered?

It oversees the records of right and wrong in the Nether Bureau. To "oversee" is to administer; it administers the records of right and wrong in the Nether Bureau, clarifying what is right and discerning what is wrong—this is the foundation of wisdom. If even a noble person governing the people must thoroughly understand this matter, how much more so the lofty perfected and sagely philosophers? One variant reads "to hook the Nether Bureau," which is incorrect.

The Five Phases share a common endowment, and the Seven Governors belong to the same category. Jupiter pertains to Wood, and the four lodges—*Jiao*, *Dou*, *Kui*, and *Jing*—share its category. Mars pertains to Fire, and the four lodges—*Wei*, *Shi*, *Zi*, and *Yi*—share its category. Venus pertains to Metal, and the four lodges—*Kang*, *Niu*, *Lou*, and *Gui*—share its category. Mercury pertains to Water, and the four lodges—*Ji*, *Bi*, *Shen*, and *Zhen*—share its category. Saturn pertains to Earth, and the four lodges—*Di*, *Nü*, *Wei*, and *Liu*—share its category. The four lodges—*Fang*, *Mao*, *Yi*, and *Xing*—are called the Solar Lodges, the abodes of the Great Yang, and are matched to Fire. The four lodges—*Xin*, *Wei*, *Bi*, and *Zhang*—are called the Lunar Lodges, the abodes of the Great Yin, and are matched to Water. These four times seven stars, together with the Five Phases and the Two Luminaries, are called the Seven Governors, all of which share the same category as the Northern Dipper. Only the Dipper’s pole governs the qi of the central heavens, revolving and regulating the celestial motions, presiding over the four directions, establishing the four seasons, harmonizing the Five Phases, and rectifying the celestial constants.

It is divided thus: *Tanlang* governs Heaven, *Jumen* governs Earth, *Lucun* governs Fire, *Wenqu* governs Water, *Kangzhen* governs Earth, *Wuqu* governs Wood, and *Pojun* governs Metal. Furthermore, *Tanlang* pertains to Water, *Jumen* and its left auxiliary pertain to Earth, *Lucun*, *Wenqu*, and *Lianzhen* pertain to Wood, *Wuqu* and *Pojun* pertain to Metal, and the *Bixing* pertains to Fire. The statutes state: "The Nine Apexes are the origin of Brahmanic qi; the Seven Governors are the fundamental net of the primal." This is what it means.

It possesses the power to reverse death and inscribe life, and the ability to dispel calamities and deliver from adversity. The Dipper stars govern the prolongation of life, the deliverance from adversity, the protection of destiny, the augmentation of lifespan, the dissolution of calamities, the dispersion of misfortunes, and the support of the declining. Thus, they possess the power to reverse death and inscribe life, to dispel calamities and deliver from adversity.

From the Son of Heaven to the common people, though their ranks differ, their allotment of destiny is without distinction. The *Illustrated Compendium of Correspondences* states: Emperor Ming of Han encountered the Seven Perfected of the Northern Dipper on Mount Zhongnan and asked, "Do I still belong to the administration of the Upper Perfected?" The Seven Perfected replied, "Though you are the lord of men, your destiny is the same as that of the common people." The emperor then bowed again and sought long life, whereupon he obtained the *Mysterious Numinous Oral Instructions*. This illustrates the principle that though ranks differ, the allotment of destiny is without distinction.

Yet most people in the world remain deluded, unaware that their bodies belong to the Northern Dipper and their destinies are decreed by the Celestial Bureau. When calamities and afflictions arise, they do not know the gate of dissolution and gratitude; when seeking blessings and praying for life, they do not understand the path of refuge. People dwell within the web of the world, yet unable to preserve their authenticity and refine their qi, to nurture the Dao and cultivate perfection, they cannot avoid calamities befalling their bodies. Even those who study the Dao but possess shallow understanding cannot escape such afflictions. Thus, the *Scripture of Numinous Treasure* states: "Even those of lesser learning may suffer illness and injury." If even Daoists cannot avoid this, how much more so the common people, who exhaust their bodies and minds in the pursuit of fame and profit, and deplete their essence and marrow in wine and lust? Morning and night, they gallop without rest, and when the time of adversity arrives, calamities will surely come.

When calamities strike, not knowing the gate of dissolution and gratitude, they rely solely on shamans and invoke heterodox spirits. Yet shamans, being petty men, recklessly speak of misfortunes and demonic influences. In times of critical illness, they submit entirely to fate, slaughtering great offerings of the three sacrificial animals to pray for deliverance. If they happen to recover, they attribute it to the grace of the spirits; if they perish, they claim the ghosts have not pardoned them. They squander grain and silk, exhausting their coffers, yet still cling to heterodox masters, their hearts never satisfied. If by chance they survive, they may yet die of hunger, cold, or starvation, or be killed by bandits, thieves, or burglars, or fall into the punishments of disgrace and evil—all of this stems from such causes.

All such cases arise from ignorance of the gate of dissolution and gratitude. Those who know this gate begin with medicinal stones; if medicinal stones fail to cure, they next pray to their ancestors; if ancestors do not respond, they then seek talismanic methods; if talismanic methods prove ineffective, they will surely have offended Heaven, and calamity will be decreed by the stars. They must then perform jiao rites, acknowledging their own life-star lord, dissolving and warding off disaster, reflecting on transgressions and repenting of sins, and praying to the Dipper Palace—thus may they dispel misfortune, resolve calamity, and prolong life to increase their allotted years.

If one neither advances by crediting good physicians and medicinal stones for healing nor retreats by attending to ancestral rites, talismanic petitions, or jiao supplications, one remains ignorant of the path of refuge. Then calamity will deepen, illness will grow perilous, and death will draw near—how grievous this is!

All this is clearly stated in the *Baopuzi*; I dare not interpret it recklessly.

Thus, when the hun-soul is bound, Mount Fengdu’s Huoluo Northern Dipper Seven Primes Great Generals and the Ghostly Palace Northern Dipper Lord divide the offices of Heavenly Courts and Earthly Bureaus. Every seven years, the living are summoned to the Northern Dipper’s yin ministry to have their sins and blessings weighed. If within those seven years one has performed good deeds, one’s official salary and lifespan will be increased, and one’s name will be reported to the Heavenly Courts. If within those seven years one has committed evil, minor offenses will reduce one’s allotted years, while major sins will bring immediate death. If one’s sins are mingled with blessings or blessings with sins, or if sins are great but blessings meager while one’s allotted years remain unfulfilled and the reckoning undetermined, then during the summons the hun-soul will be bound to the yin ministry, the body will lie stricken with illness, and suffering will be endured. When the suffering is complete, one will be severed from the human realm, die, and enter the yin ministry, sinking into evil destinies—human form forever lost.

The method of summoning souls begins at one year of age for those born in the *zi* year; at two for *chou* and *hai*; at three for *yin* and *xu*; at four for *mao* and *you*; at five for *chen* and *shen*; at six for *si* and *wei*; and at seven for *wu*. Thus, those born in *zi* begin at one year, so at eight years their soul is summoned, again at fifteen, and again at twenty-two—each summons occurring every seven years. Those who begin at two are summoned at nine, sixteen, and twenty-three, and so on. All summoned souls proceed to the official bureau of their life-star.

In the year of summons, many suffer calamities. Only those who accumulate goodness may be exempt, though even they must face one summons after two or three exemptions, for the living hun-soul must be examined for merits and faults, and the *qi* assessed. The Three Officials, Nine Bureaus, Five Emperors, and Four Departments jointly oversee this matter, reviewing and determining it at each seasonal festival. If the reckoning remains unresolved, it must be re-examined until it is precise, without the slightest error.

In the year of summons, one should perform the Dao, recite scriptures, and dissolve the *qi* of examination. Further, one may suffer from the calamity of broken oaths, or the hun-soul may be bound to earth-altars, spirit-shrines, or by the curses of heterodox masters. Misfortune will then entangle one: chronic illness may not heal, or malevolent spirits may assail, causing years of debilitation, prolonged adversity. Misfortune is the calamity of cangues and rods; chronic illness, the calamity of disease; malevolent spirits, the calamity of demonic *qi*; debilitation and adversity, the calamity of the Six Harms.

Tomb disputes and spectral summons may implicate the recently deceased. Tombs refer to the graves of ancestors; spectral summons arise when the yin ministry’s investigations extend to the living; "implicate" means the deceased transmit corpse-*qi* to burden the living. Tomb disputes are manifold, with countless variations, bringing a thousand disasters and a hundred calamities, cutting off descendants, and thwarting all endeavors—all stemming from tomb disputes. There are eighty-one types of tomb disputes, large and small, corresponding to grand and modest graves, from which disputes arise.

In broad terms: during the lifetimes of one’s nine ancestors and seven generations, transgressions are many. After death, they face numerous investigations, and if descendants have not prospered, they must redeem these debts in the netherworld, where resentment and lamentation arise. Confined to the yin ministry with no means of resolution, the Heavenly Courts investigate and impose judgments, while yin officials extend these to the living. On the Three Primes and Five La days, they are brought forth for interrogation, their descendants’ names and tomb locations examined, sins recorded, and names fixed. Descendants are subtly summoned, leading to their ruin—no trifling matter.

Moreover, improper yin-yang burial sites fall under the positions of the Northern Dipper’s Nine Stars, which determine celestial stars and earthly luminaries, the flow of mountains and waters, the depth of the burial site, the size of the Bright Hall, the height of the Four Symbols, and the orientation of the Five Tones—all governed by the Dipper Palace. If auspicious, peace ensues; if inauspicious, disputes arise. Burials at water sources, interments before spirit-temples, damaged tombs, broken coffins, overlapping graves, or new tombs encroaching on old—such cases number over a hundred, all constituting tomb disputes that harm the living. One must swiftly petition the Dipper Palace to seek dissolution.

Or one may suffer Heaven’s reproach or false accusations from below. When one accumulates sins and commits transgressions without repentance, Heaven will send down punishment, and ghosts will seize the opportunity—this is what is meant by "ghosts exploit the gaps of calamity and decline." (One version reads "false accusations" as incorrect.)

How to resolve such peril? One must urgently petition the Northern Dipper, perform jiao rites to thank the Perfected Lords, and recite the true scriptures, acknowledging one’s life-star lord—only then may one attain peace and prosperity.

For all who face such calamities, one must swiftly petition the Dipper Palace, acknowledge one’s life-star lord, reverently recite this scripture, and perform jiao rites with sincerity—thus may one attain peace and prosperity.

Moreover, there are profound mysteries that cannot be fully expounded. The scripture does not exhaust the esoteric inner teachings, for their depth and subtlety defy complete articulation. Whenever one beholds the true form of the Northern Dipper, one must bow in reverence and utmost respect.

The Dao’s image is formless, manifesting through transformation—this is what is called "the image without image, the form without form, the shape without shape." It cannot be sought through mere gazing, nor obtained through mere encounter. The so-called true form arises from the convergence of qi, born in accord with qi, embodying the essence of emptiness, naturally and spontaneously. Its foundation is luminous clarity, from which colors and images emerge. Thus, names are derived from forms, and designations established by images. The names that can be named arise as needed, for they are not fixed but contingent upon their use.

Therefore, the true form and its names reside within my heart. Though the Dao is without mind, it may be sought through sentiment; though the Dao is without sentiment, it flickers in the indistinct. When one transcends the body and abides in it, the true form is present—this is when one should bow one’s head in reverence and cultivate a heart of utmost respect.

The first star of the Northern Dipper, Yangming, is the Great Star Lord Tanlang, governing those born in the *zi* hour. The Star Lord’s surname is Ling, personal name Yaotianchui, style Tanlang. He wears a hibiscus crown, holds a jade tablet, dons a crimson robe with a purple skirt, a nine-colored azure mantle, and phoenix-embroidered shoes. In transformation, he appears as a spirit of the wilderness—his face azure, hair red and bristling upward, left hand holding a white staff, right hand resting forward.

In his true form, he wears a Nine Mornings Jade Crown, azure feathered flying garments, and wields the Dipper. The *Central Mystery Diagram* states: The Perfected Dipper Warden is titled the Jade Sovereign Nine Mornings Lord, dwelling in the Jade Tower of the Green City within the Supreme Palace. He is also called the Great Sage of the Pivot Palace □ Star Lord, or the Supporting Perfected Lord Luoshenzi, serving in heaven. He governs the Celestial Origin, acting as the Celestial Grand Commandant, overseeing the epochs of kalpas, administering governance, and rectifying transgressions. Above, he commands the perfected of the Nine Heavens; in the middle, he oversees the flying immortals of the Five Peaks; below, he leads the perfected of later learners. All spirits of heaven and earth, and the weight of merits and faults, are subject to his authority.

He governs those born in the *zi* hour, overseeing the True Lord of the Great Yang. The four lunar lodges—Room, Wall, Straddler, and Bond—along with the terrestrial divisions of Qin and Xuzhou, fall under his domain. His nodal season is Yangming, when spring engenders the myriad beings.

The *Art of Disappearance* states: The celestial name Tianying is Zuran, with hidden names in the immortal scriptures varying by method. The star spans 920 *li*. When lit as a lamp, it is called the Body Star, its brightness or dimness serving as verification. The true talisman is called the Talisman of Prolonging Life.

The second star of the Northern Dipper, Yinjing, is the Primordial Star Lord Jumen, governing those born in the *chou* and *hai* hours. The Star Lord’s surname is Yuying, personal name Jimingguang, style Jumen. He wears a Five-Colored Flying Cloud Crown, a purple robe with a yellow skirt, a seven-colored brocade mantle, and tiger-patterned shoes. In transformation, he appears as a beautiful woman, adorned with tassels and ornaments, wearing a five-colored floral crown, holding a luminous fan, attended by a blue-clad maiden.

In his true form, he wears a Dark Essence Jade Crown, black feathered flying garments, and wields a five-colored feathered staff. He is called the Dipper-Raising Perfected, titled the Jade Sovereign Northern Supreme Morning Lord, dwelling in the Five-Colored Jade Tower of the Central Origin Palace. He is also called the Great Sage of the Rotating Palace □ Star Lord, or the Infant Perfected Lord Zhenwenzi, serving in the earthly realm. He governs the Terrestrial Origin, acting as the Celestial Grand Steward, overseeing official ranks and emoluments. Above, he commands the celestial lodges; below, he leads the myriad spirits and those who study immortality. All offices of perfected immortals are subject to his authority.

He governs those born in the *chou* and *hai* hours, overseeing the True Lord of the Great Yin. The four lunar lodges—Stomach, Pleiades, Net, and Turtle Beak—along with the terrestrial divisions of Chu and Yizhou, fall under his domain. His nodal season is Yinjing, when autumn harvests the myriad beings.

The *Art of Disappearance* states: The celestial name Tianren is Yuquan. The star spans 550 *li*. When lit as a lamp, it is called the Life Star, its brightness or dimness serving as verification. The true talisman is called the Talisman of Crossing Calamity.

The third star of the Northern Dipper, the Perfected Zhenren, is the True Star Lord Luzun, governing those born in the *yin* and *xu* hours. The Star Lord’s surname is Guibing, personal name Chuzhongta, style Luzun. He wears a Nine-Colored Treasure Crown, a yellow robe with a blue skirt, a five-colored crimson mantle, and dragon-patterned shoes. In transformation, he appears as a handsome man of twenty, his flower-like face clad in grass garments, holding a brush, often standing face-forward.

In his true form, he wears a Flying Cloud Treasure Crown, azure feathered flying garments, and wields the Dipper. The *Central Azure Register* calls him the Dipper-Treading Perfected, titled the Jade Sovereign Jade Immortal Flourishing Morning Lord, dwelling in the Yellow Terrace Jade Tower of the True Origin Palace. He is also called the Great Sage of the Mechanism Palace □ Star Lord, or the Portent Perfected Lord Weifuzi, serving in the realm of fire. He governs the Solar Origin, acting as the Celestial Minister of Works, overseeing immortals. Above, he commands the lofty perfected of the Nine Heavens; in the middle, he oversees the numinous immortals of the Five Peaks; below, he leads those who study the Dao. All offices of perfected immortals are subject to his authority.

He governs those born in the *yin* and *xu* hours, overseeing the True Lord of the Water Star. The four lunar lodges—Well, Ghost, Willow, and Star—along with the terrestrial divisions of Liang and Jizhou, fall under his domain.

The *Art of Disappearance* states: The celestial name Tianzhu is Zisu. The star spans 720 *li*. When lit as a lamp, it is called the Fortune Star, its brightness or dimness serving as verification. The true talisman is called the Talisman of Preserving Life.

The fourth star of the Northern Dipper, Xuanming, is the Star Lord Wenqu of the Torsion, governing those born in the *mao* and *you* hours. The Star Lord’s surname is Lingshu, personal name Yaotian, style Wenqu. He wears a Six-Colored Coiling Dragon Crown, a white robe with a crimson skirt, a three-colored yellow mantle, and turtle-patterned shoes. In transformation, he appears as a woman—her face black, hair disheveled—holding written texts, riding a five-colored cloud dragon, glancing back at the Star Lord Lianzhen.

In his true form, he wears a Three-Flowered Treasure Crown, cinnabar brocade flying garments, and wields a Dark Numinous Staff. He is called the Dipper-Stepping Perfected, titled the Jade Sovereign Dark Supreme Flying Flourishing Morning Lord, dwelling in the Vermilion Tower Jade Tower of the Torsion Secluded Palace. He is also called the Great Sage of the Authority Palace □ Star Lord, or the Coiled Perfected Lord Zihuizi, serving in the realm of wood. He governs the Lunar Origin, acting as the Celestial Patrol Inspector, overseeing the suppression of rebellion. Above, he commands the spirits and ghosts of the Nine Heavens; in the middle, he leads the Three Palaces of the Northern Emperor; below, he governs the myriad multitudes, punishing the rebellious and disobedient, executing the wicked and perverse. All are subject to his authority.

Those born in the *mao* and *you* hours fall under the governance of the Perfected Lord of the Fire Star, encompassing the four lunar lodges of Star, Spread, Wings, and Axletree, as well as the terrestrial domains of Wu and Jingzhou. The *Dunjia* states: "The Celestial Heart is named Ziqiu, its stellar enclosure spanning eight hundred *li*. When illuminated, it is called the Star of Emolument; its brightness or dimness serves as verification. The True Talisman is named the Talisman of Augmented Lifespan."

The fifth star of the Northern Dipper, the Cinnabar Prime and Upright Integrity Star Lord of the Dipper’s Net, governs those born in the *chen* and *shen* hours. The Star Lord’s surname is Shangkai, personal name Bian, and style Lianzheng. He wears a five-colored floral crown, a blue robe with white skirt, a four-hued crimson mantle, and cloud-patterned shoes. In transformation, he appears with a single topknot, riding a white dragon, wearing a seven-jeweled crown, attended by four retainers each bearing a halberd. In his true form, he wears a seven-jeweled flying celestial crown, white brocade flying garments, and holds a register of blue *qi*. He is called the Dipper-Treading Perfected, titled the Jade Sovereign Golden Net Seven Mornings Lord, dwelling in the Net Spirit Palace’s Plain Terrace Jade Tower. He is also called the Balance Palace Great Sage □ Star Lord, or the Orchid Perfected Lord Ziweizi, serving in the realm of earth. He governs the River Origin, acting as the Celestial Dipper Lord, overseeing the registers of destiny. In the middle, he commands the ledgers of ghosts and spirits; below, he governs the life registers of the multitudes of learning perfected. All heavens and all earths are subject to his authority.

Those born in the *chen* and *shen* hours fall under the governance of the Perfected Lord of the Wood Star, encompassing the four lunar lodges of Horn, Neck, Root, and Chamber, as well as the terrestrial domains of Zhao and Yanzhou. The seasonal marker is Cinnabar Prime, and in summer, he fosters the growth of the myriad things. The *Dunjia* states: "The Celestial Quail is named Zigong, its stellar enclosure spanning seven hundred twenty *li*. When illuminated, it is called the Star of Office and Rank; its brightness or dimness serves as verification. The True Talisman is named the Talisman of Disaster Dispelling."

The sixth star of the Northern Dipper, the Northern Culmen and Martial Tally Star Lord of the Dipper’s Record, governs those born in the *si* and *wei* hours. The Star Lord’s surname is Mingling, personal name Chang Shangyuan, and style Wuqu. He wears a phoenix-soaring crown, a black robe with brocade skirt, a dragon-patterned tiger mantle, and floral-patterned shoes. In transformation, he appears with a human face atop a beast’s head, wielding a sword and draped in tassels. In his true form, he wears a flying essence floral crown, purple brocade flying garments, and holds a jade tally from the Dipper’s midst. He is called the Pace-of-the-Net Perfected, titled the Jade Sovereign Northern Culmen Flying Flourishing Morning Lord, dwelling in the Record Bright Palace’s Dark Terrace Jade Tower. He is also called the Opening Yang Palace Great Sage □ Star Lord, or the Stabilizing Perfected Lord Dachezi, serving in the realm of water. He governs the River Origin, acting as the Celestial Grand Master, overseeing court promotions. Above, he corresponds to the Perfected of the Primordial Heaven; in the middle, he commands the flying immortals of the Five Marchmounts; below, he governs the bodies of scholars. All who attain rank through meritorious service in the wheel of rebirth are subject to his authority.

Those born in the *si* and *wei* hours fall under the governance of the Perfected Lord of the Earth Star, encompassing the four lunar lodges of Heart, Tail, Winnowing Basket, and Dipper, as well as the terrestrial domains of Yan and Yangzhou. The seasonal marker is the Northern Culmen, and in winter, he gathers and stores the myriad things. The *Dunjia* states: "The Celestial Auxiliary is named Ziqing, its stellar enclosure spanning seven hundred *li*. When illuminated, it is called the Star of Longevity; its brightness or dimness serves as verification. The True Talisman is named the Talisman of Calamity Dispersing."

The seventh star of the Northern Dipper, the Celestial Thrust and Breaking Army Barrier Star Lord, governs those born in the *wu* hour. The Star Lord’s surname is Xuan Shu, personal name Kai Tian Tu, and style Pojun. He wears a seven-star crown, a cinnabar robe with brocade skirt, a tiger-headed patterned mantle, and lion-patterned shoes. In transformation, he appears with a pig’s head and human face, holding a joyous orb, or clad in plain white, exhaling red *qi* whose brilliance outshines the sun, standing at the Dipper’s head. In his true form, he wears a nine-cloud crown and nine-colored brocade garments, wielding a divine tally. He is called the Dragon-Riding Perfected, titled the Jade Sovereign General Numinous Nine Origins Northern Cover Morning Lord, dwelling in the Barrier Assembly Palace’s Nine-Layered Jade Tower. He is also called the Jade Brilliance Palace Great Sage □ Star Lord, or the Refined Perfected Lord Taibinzi, serving in the realm of metal. He governs the Sea Origin, acting as the Celestial Supreme Emperor, overseeing the mechanisms of heaven and earth—such as the length of the four seasons, the fortune or misfortune of heaven and earth, and the reckoning of kalpas—all of which are subject to his authority. Those born in the *wu* hour fall under the governance of the Perfected Lord of the Metal Star, encompassing the four lunar lodges of Ox, Girl, Void, and Rooftop, as well as the terrestrial domains of Qi and Yuzhou. He holds the handle of the Celestial Barrier, turning the wheel of the Empty Cavern without cease. The *Dunjia* states: "The Celestial Thrust is named Ziqiao, its stellar enclosure spanning nine hundred *li*. When illuminated, it is called the Star of Wives and Concubines; its brightness or dimness serves as verification. The True Talisman is named the Talisman of Supporting the Declining."

The eighth star of the Northern Dipper is the Cavern Brightness Outer Auxiliary Star Lord. The Auxiliary Star is akin to a minister or chancellor among men. The Star Lord’s surname is Jingchang, personal name Shangkai, and style Zhengyan. He wears a flying essence jeweled crown and nine-colored phoenix robes, holding fire bells. In transformation, he appears in a purple robe with a golden waistband and official’s headwrap, bearing a tablet, or adopts the attire of various states’ chief ministers. He is called the Wandering One Destiny Perfected, titled the Jade Emperor Revered Origin Morning Lord, dwelling in the Imperial Seat Palace’s Purple Hall Jade Tower. He is called the Left Auxiliary Star Lord, the Dipper’s outer auxiliary, overseeing all matters and scrutinizing the merits, demerits, blessings, and transgressions of the chief ministers of the myriad states and nine provinces. The *Dunjia* states: "The Celestial Inner is named Tiancheng. When illuminated, it wards off misfortunes, cures illnesses, and administers medicines; brightness bodes well, while dimness portends ill."

The eighth palace, the Imperial Seat Palace, is where the Empress of Transformation, the High Sovereign’s Left Consort of the Dipper’s midst, resides. Her name is Taiyi Buqizhu, and her style Luozhi. She wears a luxuriant purple brocade mantle and an embroidered feather flying cinnabar skirt. The two stars of Auxiliary and Aligned alternate in visibility: when visible, it is called the Auxiliary, which lies beside the Martial Tally Star.

The ninth star of the Northern Dipper is the Hidden Brilliance Inner Aligned Star Lord. The Aligned Star is akin to a minister or chancellor among men. The Star Lord’s surname is Youkong, personal name Ming Yanghui, and style Youliao. He wears a flying celestial jeweled crown and holds an imperial decree. In transformation, he appears in court robes, bearing a jade tablet, exhaling five-colored *qi*, or adopts the attire of various states’ chief ministers. He is called the Lingering Three Yangs Perfected, titled the Jade Emperor Pure Origin Morning Lord, dwelling in the Supreme Palace’s Purple Hall Jade Tower. He is called the Right Aligned Star Lord, the Dipper’s inner aligned, overseeing all matters and scrutinizing the merits, demerits, blessings, and transgressions of the chief ministers of the myriad states and nine provinces.

The *Dun Jia* states: The Heavenly Penetrating Star’s style is Ziqin. When lighting lamps, one prays for blessings; affairs undertaken openly bring good fortune, while those concealed bring misfortune. ○ Furthermore, the Ninth Supreme Palace’s Imperial Transmutation Golden Stone Mountain River Dipper’s High Sovereign Right Consort is named Taiyi Di, styled Yunyu, adorned in dark green embroidered shawls and kingfisher-feathered skirts. The Nine Right Consorts all wear cloud-tousled buns. Another hidden star is called the Aligned Star, which resides beside the inner edge of the Great Gate Star.

The Upper Terrace’s Void Essence Opening Virtue Star Lord.
The Middle Terrace’s Sixfold Purity Controller of Emptiness Star Lord.
The Lower Terrace’s Crooked Life Controller of Fortune Star Lord.

The Upper Terrace Star Lord is named Void Essence, his face crimson, exhaling red *qi*, hair unbound in Daoist robes, holding a green jade tablet, riding black clouds, with yellow *qi* crowning his head.
The Middle Terrace Star Lord is named Sixfold Purity, also called Sixfold Pavilion, his face white, exhaling white *qi* that fills the heavens, dressed in Daoist robes, holding a white jade tablet, riding white clouds, with white *qi* crowning his head.
The Lower Terrace Star Lord is named Crooked Life, his face small yet radiant with a thousand beams, *qi* like threads piercing the dark, standing amid blue-green *qi*, clad in Daoist robes, holding a blue-green jade tablet.

The Three Terraces comprise six stars, shining in pairs, called the Celestial Stairway. In heaven, they are the Three Terraces; in rank, the Three Dukes; in man, the Three Hun. They array the Grand Stair to assist the Emperor’s throne.
The two stars of the Upper Terrace: the upper star governs emperors, the lower star governs empresses.
The two stars of the Middle Terrace: the upper star governs feudal lords and the Three Dukes, the lower star governs ministers and grandees.
The two stars of the Lower Terrace: the upper star governs scholars, the lower star governs commoners.

The Three Terraces receive the three *qi* of emptiness—luminous blue-green, yellow, and white—true colors that harmonize yin and yang. The *Southern Dipper Sutra* states: The Southern Dipper molds the *hun*; the Northern Dipper forges the *po*—this is the principle of yin and yang’s molding and forging. Yin and yang smelt and refine to generate our spirit; only after the spirit descends into the womb can life take form. The Terrace (*tai*) is the womb (*tai*); threefold and doubled, the nine *qi* are thus attained. Hence, within the golden chamber and jade hall, the embryo is nested in nine layers. Man receives his substance from yin and yang and binds his *hun* to the Three Terraces. The *hun* is yang, moving to generate life; the *po* is yin, still to stabilize. When man’s movement and stillness do not lose the harmony of yin and yang, his form is firmly secure. This is what is meant by the Three Terraces giving me life, nurturing me, and protecting me.

The Northern Dipper governs the source of water; the Southern Dipper governs the abode of fire—these two Dippers are the great agents of generation and completion. The Southern Dipper’s true yang fire is stored in *kan*; the Northern Dipper’s true one water is stored in *li*. The two *qi* ascend and descend, coming and going in union, achieving the hexagram *Jiji* (Completion). All things flourish and prosper—this is the foundation of the Dao. Water is the number one; multiplied by five, it becomes the Southern Dipper’s six stars. Fire is the number two; multiplied by five, it becomes the Northern Dipper’s seven stars. Each subtracts five to leave three—three is the number of generation, hence the Three Terraces. The stars of the Southern and Northern Dippers total thirteen; in man’s body, they correspond to thirteen matters. The Most High said: “Those who follow life are thirteen; those who follow death are thirteen.” This is the Dao. To know it and practice it is to live; to not know it and not practice it is to die. The handle of life and death lies in the power of yin and yang. The six stars of the Three Terraces represent three yin and three yang. This speaks of thirteen stars, yet the Three Terraces are not counted separately—they are within them. The Terrace stars number six, yet the Star Lords are three, for the three *qi* divide into six, called the Six *Qi*. Reunited, they become three; reunited again, the Six *Qi* are balanced, the Three Powers are at peace. Three transforms into six, six transforms into three—thus heaven and earth endure forever, without end.

**True Talisman of the Three Terraces**
The true names and titles of these Perfected Lords cannot be heard. Whoever sees or hears them and can recite them possesses profound Daoist devotion and deep karmic affinity from past lives. To hear and recite them brings merit and power beyond measure.

The *Northern Dipper Original Destiny Sutra*, transmitted by the Thirty-Six Heavenly Star Controllers of Destiny and the Celestial Capital Protector of Life Great Heavenly Emperor, states: Long ago, when the Primordial Supreme Lord was expounding the Dao in the Jade Purity Yellow Ultimate Palace, a Perfected named Baoshang, foremost among the Heavenly Sons, stepped forward and asked: “The seven stars of the Central Heaven, majestic and resplendent, govern all luminaries, revolve the *qi* of destiny, and weigh life and death. Their awe-inspiring power is most profound. By what cause and condition do they hold this preeminent supremacy? From which kalpa did they arise, and what is the transformation of their beginning and end? I wish to hear this in detail.”

The Supreme Lord said: “Great is your question! In the distant Dragon Han kalpa, there was a king named Zhou Yu, whose sagely virtue knew no bounds. The people of his time enjoyed lifespans of eighty-four thousand great kalpas. The king had a jade consort, wise and compassionate, named the Purple Light Lady. In the kalpas of dust, she had already vowed to bear a sagely son to assist heaven and earth and aid in creation. After three thousand kalpas, she was born in this king’s era. On an early spring day, when a hundred flowers bloomed in splendor, she strolled in the rear garden and came to the Golden Lotus Flower Warm Jade Pool. There, she disrobed to bathe and suddenly felt a stirring. Nine lotus buds appeared and opened in due time, giving birth to nine sons. The two eldest were the Heavenly Sovereign Great Emperor and the Purple Tenuity Great Emperor. The seven younger sons became the Seven Stars, who, whether good or ill, transformed and guided the multitudes. After seven days and nights in the jade pool, they coalesced into radiant light and flew to the Central Ultimate, ninety million *li* from earth, where they transformed into nine great treasure palaces. The two eldest sovereigns resided in the Purple Tenuity Enclosure’s Grand Void Palace at the *Gouchen* position, wielding the floating tower, upholding the principles of primordial transformation, and serving as the lords of all stars.”

The Venerable Lady of Purple Radiance, honored as the Heavenly Empress of the Nine Perfected Saints of Virtue and Power of the Northern Dipper. Such are the names and titles of these True Lords—had they not been revealed by the Treasure Supreme, expounded by the Jade Purity, and personally bestowed by the Heavenly Sovereign upon the Celestial Master, they would remain unknown to the world. Those who hear and recite them do so by virtue of profound Dao-mind and long-cultivated good affinity; if they further uphold the scripture and practice its teachings, their merit shall be beyond all reckoning.

For faithful men and women who encounter this true scripture, their wisdom-nature is complete. Those who believe and revere it foresee events before they arise and illumine them as they occur; their nature moves in perfect roundness, like a ring without end, never stagnating upon things. The Dao-mind unfolds—this mind, pure in celestial principle, awakens and manifests, transcending the paths of dark delusion and penetrating the gates of the mysterious and wondrous. It departs from the byways of confusion, enters the Gate of the Inaudible and Invisible, returns to the true lineage, and attains the realm of flourishing life.

To seek and return to it is to serve the true lineage—*true* signifies no need for external pursuit, while *lineage* refers to the Lords of the Northern Dipper. To comprehend and awaken to this is to enter the realm of flourishing—*flourishing* denotes the unborn and undying, and *realm* encompasses the domains of humans and heavens, all by virtue of encountering this true scripture.

On the Three Primordials—
the fifteenth day of the first month of the Upper Primordial,
the fifteenth day of the seventh month of the Middle Primordial,
and the fifteenth day of the tenth month of the Lower Primordial—
the Three Officials of the Three Primordials, who govern the hundred bureaus, ascend to the heavenly courts to present the records of human transgressions and blessings, weighing their depth and severity. They convene in the Dipper Palace, and thus one should perform the Dao, recite the scriptures, and conduct rites.

On the Eight Nodal Days—
the four *li* (spring, autumn, winter, summer beginnings),
the two solstices,
and the two equinoxes—
the Eight Radiant Sovereigns and the Five Emperors descend to record human good and evil. As the nodal *qi* stirs in response to destiny, transgressions bring calamitous *qi*, while merit summons blessed *qi*; on these days, one should perform the Dao and recite the scriptures.

On the *Benming* Days—
the *jiazi* of one’s birth year, which recurs every sixty days—
and on one’s Birthday—
the day of one’s birth, when the myriad spirits of the body gather—
one should perform the Dao and recite the scriptures to repay the grace of the stars’ illumination and the toil of one’s parents.

On the Days of the Northern Dipper’s Descent—
the twenty-fifth and twenty-sixth days of the first month;
the second, seventh, twenty-third, and twenty-sixth days of the second month;
the twenty-sixth day of the third month;
the seventeenth and twenty-seventh days of the fourth month;
the fifth, thirteenth, and twentieth days of the fifth month;
the fourth and eighth days of the sixth month;
the fourth and twenty-fourth days of the seventh month;
the third, eleventh, nineteenth, and twenty-seventh days of the eighth month;
the third and eighteenth days of the ninth month;
the tenth and twenty-sixth days of the tenth month;
the first, ninth, seventeenth, and twenty-fifth days of the eleventh month;
and the twentieth day of the twelfth month.
(For intercalary months, follow the preceding month.)

The above are the days when the Northern Dipper descends to traverse the earthly realm. Additionally, the *gengshen* and *jiazi* days, as well as the third and seventh days of each month, are also considered days of the Northern Dipper’s descent.

When one solemnly establishes an altar, recites the scriptures, and performs the fast and offerings in accordance with the rites, the blessings are boundless. Life after life, one shall not stray from true nature nor fall into heterodox views. Those who uphold this scripture and constantly recite the honorific titles of the Seven Perfected Lords of the Primordials shall perfect their good merit and summon auspiciousness.

*Solemnly* denotes reverence, caution, and meticulous order; *establishes* means to erect. The *altar* refers to the platform constructed for fasts and offerings, where one recites the scriptural texts and follows the ritual forms to perform the Dao. The power of such blessings is vast, extending universally without limit. Life after life, one turns toward truth and away from falsehood, never losing one’s true nature. When cultivation reaches this point, the empty chamber fills with light, and auspiciousness naturally arrives.

Then is spoken the Incantation of the Northern Dipper:

This incantation of the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper originates from the True Rites of the Heavenly Heart. It dispels evil and cures illness, serving all purposes—truly the great incantation of the numinous texts beneath the Dipper.

The Nine Luminaries of the Northern Dipper, Great Spirits of the Central Heaven.
The Nine Luminaries refer to the Seven Stars and the two honored stars of the Sovereigns. The incantation includes the names of all nine, though later generations altered it to the Seven Stars, omitting the two luminaries.

A note explains: In heaven, they are called *spirits*; on earth, *numina*; among humans, *ghosts*. Only humans occupy the middle realm. Those who cultivate may ascend to become immortals or descend to become numinous beings, while those who do not cultivate perish when their *qi* is exhausted, becoming ghosts. Ghosts, in turn, may transform into humans. Only humans are capable of all transformations and all penetrations.

The Northern Dipper is the honored one of the Central Heaven, the chief of the Three Spirits, and thus called the Great Spirit.
Ascending to the Golden Gates,
The Golden Gates of the Jade Capital are the capital of the August Emperor of the Void. The Northern Dipper serves as a minister to the Three Pure Ones and the Jade Emperor, hence it is said to ascend and pay homage.

Descending to cover Kunlun,
Kunlun Mountain is the peak of the heavens, located within the Eight Seas. It stands at the center of the sky, its shape like an inverted canopy, broad above and narrow below. In three tiers, it rises to the level of the heavens, aligning with the center of the ten thousand degrees. The yellow and red paths intersect upon it, and the Three Luminaries traverse it.

To the east, it is called Kunlun; to the west, Dark Garden; to the north, Towering Wind; to the south, Accumulated Stones. A great precipice and springs lie at its northern gate. The mountain spans ten thousand *li* on each of its four sides. At its summit stand palaces of jasper blossoms and terraces of luminous jade. The Jasper Pool and Emerald Waters are where the Queen Mother of the West governs the host of perfected beings.

At the mountain’s highest peak stand five golden terraces, twelve jade towers, and nine layers of golden walls. The earth gives rise to trees of golden roots and forests of jasper branches, bearing fruits of plain blossoms. There are jasper springs and jade streams, purple phoenixes and emerald simurghs, green peaches and purple crabapples. A hundred treasures adorn it, beyond all reckoning.

The palaces where the Dipper and Pole Star reside each number five, each with five gates, and each gate emits fourfold radiance, blazing to illuminate ninety thousand *li*. Below, they govern the nine *qi* and eight luminaries, each presiding over a celestial region. The four *qi* give rise to life, and at their center stands the Pillar of Heaven, ascending to the Celestial Pass. They encompass the thirty-five divisions of the Upper Prime, each serving as the great life-generating pivot of the celestial mechanism—thus it is said they overspread Kunlun.

They regulate the cosmic order: the nine celestial bodies are the scions of the August Ultimate, governing the numbers of the Three and Five to harmonize the great transformations. From these transformations emerge the Five Phases, Five Affairs, Eight Governances, Five Constants, Three Powers, divination rites, myriad policies, Five Blessings, and their applications. Truly aligning with the human Dao to rectify the cosmic order—thus did Yao follow the August Heaven, and Shun align the Seven Governors.

They command and encompass Heaven and Earth, enveloping the cosmos—thus it is called "command and control."

The names of the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper are: Great Culmen (Pole Star), Greedy Wolf, Giant Gate, Wealth Storage, Literary Curvature, Integrity and Chastity, Martial Curvature, and Broken Army. These are the titles of the Star Lords, inscribed upon their true forms.

The Highest Jade Emperor is the most revered star within the Dipper, residing near the first star in the Dipper’s bowl. Those who behold it attain a lifespan of six hundred years.

The Purple Tenuity Emperor Lord is the imperial star within the Dipper, also called the Grand Tenuity Emperor Lord. It lies near the fourth star in the Dipper’s bowl, and those who see it live three hundred years. These two august stars serve as the teachers of all phenomena and the focal point toward which the host of stars pay homage.

The Seven Perfected of the Northern Dipper declare: "Our ancestral master, the Northern Culmen, through kalpas of diligent devotion—offering incense and lamps to the Three Clarities—fulfilled his merit and perfected his virtue. Ascending into the Purple Tenuity, he comes and goes with a canopy of blossoms following, his starlight ever resplendent with the seven treasures, shining upward to the heavens and downward to the ten thousand lands. On the third and twenty-seventh days of each month, he descends to inspect the good and evil of humankind."

In former times, Guo Ziyi, Prince of Fenyang, encountered an immortal who taught him the method of observing the stars. He was told: "On the third and twenty-seventh nights of each month, in the stillness of night, let no one know. Secretly descend to the central courtyard and gaze upon the Dipper. If you see two stars whose radiance is as vast as a chariot wheel, these are the two august imperial stars. Do not speak of this to others, and you may attain longevity." Guo Ziyi, preoccupied with state affairs, did not practice this, but his maidservant, Huanche Jie, who attended him in his chamber, secretly read these words in his pillow book. She practiced in secret and succeeded in beholding them. Even in the Song dynasty, she remained within the palace. Today, the days when the Northern Culmen descends originate from this.

The great expanse of the celestial realm extends even to the finest mote of dust. The *qi* of yin and yang, vast as the turning heavens or minute as a speck of dust—what do they not reach? What calamity do they not extinguish? What blessing do they not bring to fruition? "To fruition" means to arrive and to gather. All misfortunes and disasters are entirely dissolved, and all auspicious fortunes naturally converge—this is what is meant by "calamities and obstacles cannot intrude, all depending on the generation of a hundred blessings."

The primordial and august *qi* comes to merge with my body. The *Jue of Absorbing the Primordial August Qi* states: "Azure, black, yellow, red, white, green, crimson, jade-green, and profound light—from one to nine, absorb the *qi* and consume the primordial yellow. Daily, unite with the august *qi*. The seven orifices generate radiant blossoms. After nine years, merit and practice are fulfilled, and one enters to serve in the Nine Morning Chambers."

The method states: The primordial yellow and august *qi* are the true *qi* of the Eight Trigrams and Nine Palaces, descending from the Nine August Ones to generate the ten thousand existences.

The First, Yang Brightness: the divine person exhales the light of azure *qi*.
The Second, Yin Essence: the divine person exhales the light of black *qi*.
The Third, Perfected Person: the divine person exhales the light of yellow *qi*.
The Fourth, Profound Darkness: the divine person exhales the light of red *qi*.
The Fifth, Cinnabar Prime: the divine person exhales the light of white *qi*.
The Sixth, Northern Culmen: the divine person exhales the light of green *qi*.
The Seventh, Heavenly Impulse: the divine person exhales the light of crimson *qi*.
The Eighth, Assistant Star: the divine person exhales the light of jade-green *qi*.
The Ninth, Adjuvant Star: the divine person exhales the light of profound *qi*.

The method of absorbing *qi* is as follows: During the first, fourth, seventh, and tenth months—the four *meng* months—practice at dawn on the first nine days of the first decade. During the second, fifth, eighth, and eleventh months—the four *zhong* months—practice at noon on the nineteenth day of the middle decade. During the third, sixth, ninth, and twelfth months—the four *ji* months—practice at midnight on the twenty-ninth day of the last decade. Perform this thrice monthly—at dawn, noon, and midnight—adjusting according to the *meng*, *zhong*, and *ji* months. Over a year, this amounts to thirty-six sessions, corresponding to the three hundred sixty degrees of the celestial sphere, with five as the surplus to complete the *qi*.

On the days and hours of practice, enter a purified chamber, burn incense, and concentrate the mind. Close the eyes, hold the breath, and click the teeth nine times. Visualize the divine lords of the Nine Palaces and star mansions seated in majesty, surrounded by an awe-inspiring retinue. Silently recite the incantation: *"The great divine of the Northern Dipper’s primordial epoch in the center of heaven arrives... [missing characters]... august emperor, swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by the law!"*

Then see the nine *qi* descending from the stars and flowing into the mouth. With each breath, exhale the old *qi* and gradually inhale the new *qi*, ensuring no sound reaches the ears. Swallow the nine-colored *qi* completely, click the teeth nine times, and suddenly forget all. Body and spirit unite in subtlety. Whether sitting, lying, moving, or resting, maintain harmonious adjustment. Practicing thus for nine years, the Nine Star Lords will descend to bestow upon you their secrets. You will become a long-lived immortal, ascend to the Three Heavens, befriend the host of perfected beings, and merge with the Dao in truth.

The handle of the Dipper points ceaselessly, day and night revolving. The Dipper’s handle in the heavens turns without error, moving from *zi* to *hai*, shifting one position each watch. As the poem says, "All day long, the seven attendants"—this is it.

Annotation: Each month, it constantly adds to *xu*; at all times, Broken Army is visible. To receive the true *qi*, one should face this direction.

The term "vulgar dweller" is a self-deprecating title used by disciples of the Dao, referring to themselves as "walking corpses in a defiled world" or "filthy beings of the mortal realm." In old manuscripts, the character *su* (俗) was half-eroded by bookworms, leaving only its lower portion; later scholars mistakenly reconstructed it as *ke* (恪) or *ge* (格), and more recently, it has been further corrupted to *ge* (隔) based on pronunciation.

Those who cherish the Dao and seek the numinous do so by revering the mysterious and efficacious scriptures and oral instructions, pursuing their profound wonders. They wish to behold the august countenance and forever preserve long life. *Yi* (仪) refers to the form and appearance—the true visage of the exalted Emperor. As the method states: "May your servant soon behold it; beholding it is long life."

The Three Terraces are void and essence,
The Six Curved Stars give birth and life,
They nourish and sustain me,
They guard my body and form.

The Lord Lao declares: For all people, their nature, life, and five bodies are entirely governed by the star officials of their original destiny. "Nature" refers to the celestial mandate of one's nature; "life" means that which transforms yet remains unchanging; "five bodies" are the two hands, two feet, and head. The "star officials of original destiny" denote the star officials corresponding to the sixty *jiazi* cyclical years. Whatever Heaven bestows and humanity receives is all under the governance of these star officials of original destiny, without the slightest deviation.

The divine generals of one’s original destiny—these refer to the celestial stems and branches of one’s birth year, month, day, and hour, as well as the year, month, day, and hour of gestation, collectively termed "fetal birth." They comprise the eight divine generals: the *yin-yang*, male-female, reverse-sequential, and fate-bound generals, along with the generals of *lu* (禄) and *ma* (马) *qi*, the attendant officials of original destiny, the talismanic spirits, and the scribal deities.

The star officials of one’s original constellation—these are the twenty-eight stellar sovereigns of the lunar lodges. There are two types of original constellation stars: first, the star sovereign presiding over the year of one’s birth. For instance, in the *jiazi* year, the Horn Lodge governs the year, making the Horn Lodge’s Celestial Gate Star Sovereign the star official of one’s original constellation. The second type is determined by the "fowl divination" method to fix the star of fetal breath and life, with three positions governing the three *yuan* (元) and three fate-bound periods—also termed the star officials of one’s original constellation. They perpetually bestow hidden protection, sustaining human life to preserve one’s celestial years. The span of celestial years is one hundred and twenty years. Those who uphold the Dao of the *Beidou Scripture for Extending Life* will find their divine generals of original destiny and star officials of their original constellation constantly shielding them, governing their life to fulfill their allotted years. Yet the common folk, lacking understanding, remain oblivious throughout their lives. The impure substance of the womb, devoid of awareness, never comprehends this principle.

The true officials of original destiny descend to the mortal realm six times each year, and the day of their descent marks the fate-bound period of one’s original destiny. Whenever this day arrives, it becomes the appointed limit—once every sixty days, six times a year. When the true officials descend, the fate-bound period of one’s original destiny spans one hundred and twenty years as two limits: sixty years as a minor limit, and one hundred twenty years as the major limit. When the limit is exhausted, death follows. Should one violate prohibitions and offend against their allotted years, their fate-bound period shortens. But those who accumulate yang merits, perform yin virtues, adhere to precepts and prohibitions, and revere the celestial mandate will find their limit extended—and with the extension of their limit, their life is prolonged.

There are three thousand Southern Mound Envoys, transformations of yang, where three *qi* coalesce into spirits.

The Seven Thousand Divine Generals of the Northern Dipper True Lord are transformations of yin, where seven *qi* coalesce into spirits. When the True Official of one’s original destiny descends in majesty, all the perfected beings gather to protect and shield. This can dispel calamities, repent sins, invoke blessings, and prolong life. According to one’s capacity, one may present petitions and perform jiao rites, thereby augmenting and exalting their fortune and virtue. On the day of the descent, all the perfected beings arrive to guard and defend, and one may present petitions, perform jiao rites, repent sins, dispel calamities, prolong life, and invoke blessings. According to one’s capacity, one may establish merit, thereby augmenting and exalting their fortune and virtue.

Should the limit of one’s original destiny be approaching and one remains unaware, failing to prepare vegetarian feasts or jiao rites, neglecting incense and offerings—this is to treat life lightly, to be deluded about one’s origin, and to disdain the human form. The celestial bureaus will strip away one’s emoluments, reduce one’s allotted years, and curtail one’s lifespan, often leading to premature death. If, as the limit of one’s original destiny approaches, one remains unaware, failing to prepare vegetarian feasts or jiao rites, to uphold the scriptural precepts, or to pay homage to the Dipper Perfected—this is to treat this life lightly, to forget one’s origin, and to debase one’s own body. The celestial bureaus will surely strip away one’s emoluments, reduce one’s allotted years, and thus many will die prematurely, unable to fulfill their destined years.

Those who are deluded, even if they encounter the scriptural precepts, harbor disbelief and slander the true texts. Such individuals, after their bodies perish, will sink into the Three Wretched Realms and drift through the Six Destinies, forever losing the human form. Deeply lamentable, they bring this suffering upon themselves. Human delusion and error, even when encountering the scriptural precepts, lead some to harbor disbelief and even slander. After death, they fall into the Three Wretched Realms and Six Destinies, never again to attain a human body. As the saying goes: "Heaven-made calamities may yet be avoided, but self-made calamities are inescapable." Though the Heavenly Worthy, moved by compassion, may arouse pity, the enforcers of the law must often grant leniency.

If, on the day of one’s original destiny, one prepares vegetarian feasts and jiao rites, and skillfully petitions the celestial bureaus, then for one lifetime at the limit of one’s original destiny, one may recite the true scriptures, abundantly present offerings, and thereby ensure that for three lifetimes one will always be reborn as a man—wealthy, noble, intelligent, and preeminent among humanity. If, on the day of one’s original destiny in this life, one adheres to the precepts and prohibitions, recites the true scriptures, and grandly performs vegetarian feasts and jiao rites, then for three lifetimes one will be reborn as a man—wealthy, noble, intelligent, and uniquely distinguished among humanity.

For those whose karmic endowment in this life is meager, though born among humanity, they may be poor and lowly. Even if they know their original destiny but lack the means to perform grand rites, if they can pour water and offer flowers, sincerely face the North Pole, bow their heads in reverence, and invoke the name of the True Lord of their original destiny, they will not pass their destined limit in vain. They will all attain life prolongation and fortune inscription, perpetually retaining the human form. Calamities will be dispelled, and boundless blessings will be obtained. If one is born poor and lowly, though aware of their original destiny, lacks the means to establish merit, yet can pour water and offer flowers, devoutly face the North Pole, bow their heads in reverence, and invoke the name of the Northern Dipper’s Star Lord of their original destiny, they will not pass their destined day in vain. They will all attain life prolongation and fortune inscription, perpetually retaining the human form. Calamities will be forever dispelled, and boundless blessings will be obtained.

The Heavenly Master rejoiced, leapt with joy, and bowed in reverence, praising the rarity of encountering this unsurpassed Dharma Bridge. The Heavenly Master, having received the scriptural Dharma, rejoiced and praised it, likening it to a Dharma Bridge—its crossing is endless, truly rare to encounter.

The Old Lord further addressed the Heavenly Master: The sins and blessings, good and evil of worldly people all belong to the celestial bureaus. To repent sins and dispel calamities, nothing surpasses cultivation and reverence. The sins and blessings, good and evil of worldly people are all governed by the Dipper Spirits. If one wishes to repent and cleanse transgressions, to dispel and avert calamities, nothing surpasses preparing vegetarian feasts, performing jiao rites, and cultivating reverence in accordance with the scriptures.

On the day of one’s original destiny, the day of the body’s inscription at the Zhongyuan Festival, and the day of the Yuanchen—there are two types of Yuanchen. The first is based on the Northern Dipper’s Seven Origins establishing life, where the Star Lord of one’s original destiny has left and right assistants as the Yuanchen. For yang men and yin women, the position preceding the clash is called the Yuanchen; for yin men and yang women, the position following the clash is called the Yuanchen. For example, if a man is born in the *zi* hour, *Tanlang* is the Star Lord of his original destiny, and *Zuofu* is the Yuanchen Star Lord. If a woman is born in the *zi* hour, *Tanlang* is the Star Lord of her original destiny, and *Youbi* is the Yuanchen Star Lord. If a man is born in the *chou* or *hai* hour, *Jumen* is the Star Lord of his original destiny, and *Youbi* is the Yuanchen Star Lord; for a woman, *Zuofu* is the Yuanchen Star Lord. The rest follow this pattern.

The second type is based on the sixty *jiazi* cycles as the Star Officials of one’s original destiny. In the Mysterious Numinosity method, they are called the Great Generals of the Original Destiny. For example, if a man is born in the *jiazi* year, *xinhai* is the Yuanchen Star Official; for a woman, *jisi* is the Yuanchen Star Official. If a man is born in the *yichou* year, *renwu* is the Yuanchen Star Official; for a woman, *jiashen* is the Yuanchen Star Official. The rest follow this pattern. Further, within the Five *Zi* Origins, one may discern the true and false. On these days, when the Yuanchen descends, one should purify the body, observe abstinence, practice the Dao, and recite scriptures.

The Yuanchen must never be offended. If one is born under the Yuanchen’s influence in one’s destiny, one will not escape its misfortunes in this lifetime. Though this is predetermined by heavenly mandate, one may repent and make amends on the day of the Yuanchen’s descent, transforming calamities into blessings. The Star Lords, Star Officials, Divine Generals, talismanic clerks, and their retinues of one’s original destiny hold positions of lord and minister, with clear distinctions of rank—yet people remain unaware of this.

The Post Horse: The Five Blessings Post Horse Divine Lord is an auspicious spirit of one’s original destiny. For those born in the *shen-zi-chen* years, it resides in the *yin* position; for those born in the *si-you-chou* years, it resides in the *hai* position; for those born in the *yin-wu-xu* years, it resides in the *shen* position; for those born in the *hai-mao-wei* years, it resides in the *si* position. The position corresponding to the decade of one’s birth is the primary position.

The Three Calamities of Diminution and Nine Adversities of Misfortune—this annotation refers to the preceding text on preserving one’s present kin and ensuring their peace. The *Scripture of Central Prohibitions* states: "The people flicker like fireflies, each bearing a star. Every person has their own star of original destiny, with their own calamities and blessings. Yet, in general, these must follow the master *qi*. For a nation, the emperor and his ministers are the master *qi*; for a household, the family head is the master *qi*."

The master *qi* endowed with the Dao can reverse celestial principles, transform calamity into fortune—my destiny lies within me, not in Heaven. This Dao encompasses Heaven and Earth, grasps yin and yang, and thus neither great fate can constrain it nor can yin and yang assail it. Yet if one fails to practice the Dao and perform meritorious deeds, one cannot escape the bounds of destiny.

During the critical junctures of yearly and monthly adversities, one should await the resolution of hardship. If, however, one recklessly squanders life and loses sight of its origin, failing to cherish the human form, indulging in the three karmic actions, and unrestrainedly pursuing the six senses, accumulating transgressions and multiplying offenses, calamities will inevitably strike with severity. This may extend to implicating one’s kin, bringing misfortune upon the entire household—no small matter indeed.

Why is this so? Because the six relations and family members all arise from the primordial origin of one’s own destiny. For instance, those who give birth to me are my mother; those who raise me are my father; those of the same kind are my siblings; those I restrain are my wife and wealth; those I engender are my children and grandchildren—all stem from the primordial origin of my destiny. Furthermore, adding the number of months from one’s birth month to the hour of birth determines the "destiny official." For men and women, these are arranged in reverse or sequential order, forming the twelve positions: first, the Palace of Destiny; second, the Palace of Wealth; third, the Palace of Siblings; fourth, the Palace of Fields and Dwellings; fifth, the Palace of Children and Grandchildren; sixth, the Palace of Servants; seventh, the Palace of Wives and Concubines; eighth, the Palace of Jealousy and Adversity; ninth, the Palace of Migration; tenth, the Palace of Official Rank and Emolument; eleventh, the Palace of Fortune and Virtue; twelfth, the Palace of Appearance. Applying the three *yuan*, four residences, and five phases, along with the stems and branches, to these positions, as they move through the yearly positions and the limits of one’s fate, one encounters calamity as calamity and fortune as fortune. Thus, one should first invoke and supplicate the primordial origin of one’s destiny and the *Yima* deity.

The primordial origin is one’s heart. For all people, the primordial origin is outwardly manifested in the eyes and inwardly concealed in the heart. The eyes survey the myriad things externally, while the heart races internally through the ten thousand affairs. Wherever the heart and eyes roam, the spirit also hastens—hence it is called the *Yima* of the primordial origin, ceaselessly galloping through affairs without respite.

If one can gather the heart and return to inner illumination, preserving the mysterious numen within, then one halts the galloping horse to manure the fields, inwardly nurturing form and spirit, solidifying embryonic breathing. Thereafter, the Three Corpses depart the body, the Nine Worms perish, and from whence could the Three Calamities and Nine Adversities arise? In due time, one receives destiny, and the hundred spirits harmonize and flourish—this is what is meant by the peace and tranquility of one’s kin.

Whenever an adept—one who cultivates the Dao—holds this true scripture on their destiny’s birthdate, they externally subdue demonic spirits and internally pacify their true nature. Those who cultivate the Dao are called adepts; reciting this scripture on their destiny’s birthday enables them to externally subdue demonic spirits and internally nourish spirit and nature, naturally attaining the Dao and achieving perfection. Their merit extends to the realms of water and land; those who achieve the Dao bestow their virtue upon all beings, so that creatures that fly, walk, sink, or hide all receive its blessings.

Its blessings extend to both the living and the departed; when one attains the Dao, their kin find peace and tranquility, and the nine generations of ancestors and seven lineages of descendants all receive its grace. Through repentance and reverence, one gradually ascends to the wondrous fruit. By reestablishing profound merit and realizing the Dao of emptiness and non-being, one attains the perfect wisdom of the sages, their presence as elusive as the hidden radiance, moving between existence and non-existence, roaming the clouds at will, ascending through the Golden Gate to unite with the sacred and true. Their form transcends the Three Realms, forever freed from the cycle of rebirth, their lifespan boundless, their joy and freedom complete.

When one repents with reverence, the wondrous fruit and profound merit may be attained and established—this is the Dao, the inexhaustible source of life and transformation, the ceaseless flow of existence. Human life arises from emptiness and non-being, where spirit transforms into qi, and qi transforms into essence, thus taking form. The way of its application: the wise do not expend it externally but direct it inward, so that essence returns to qi, qi returns to spirit, and refining spirit to merge with the Dao, one reattains the wondrous state of emptiness and non-being. Spirit transforms without fixed form—this is the work of the sages. To know all things is to possess wisdom that pervades the myriad beings, yet the subtle and mysterious, the profoundly unknowable, remain beyond comprehension. Thus, their presence is as elusive as hidden radiance, moving between existence and non-existence, roaming the clouds at will, ascending through the Golden Gate. Form and spirit both attain perfection, uniting with the Dao in truth, returning together to the great transformation of the Three Purities. No longer bound by the cycle of rebirth, their lifespan knows no end, and they abide in carefree non-action, their primordial destiny fulfilled.

Whenever men or women, on their destiny’s birthdate or during days of purification, purify body and mind, burn incense, and hold this true scripture; recognizing the star lord of their destiny under the Northern Dipper and offering sincere prayers, no good shall go unanswered. Disasters and transgressions dissolve, and the ten thousand sages and thousand perfected beings all come to guard and protect.

The Orthodox Unity Perfected Master, Celestial Master Zhang of Han, spoke to his disciple Zhao Sheng: "The human body possesses three hun-souls: one governs destiny, one governs wealth and rank, and one governs misfortune and decline. It is also said that one hun-soul resides in the celestial palace of its destined star, one in the earthly prison, and one within the body. The seven po-souls constantly dwell within and do not disperse. The hun-souls belong to yang and move to give life, while the po-souls belong to yin and remain still to stabilize the form.

On one’s destiny’s birthdate, when the hun-souls descend into the body and unite with the corpse, they observe its appearance—whether it is withered or robust, weak or strong. If the three hun-souls circulate and descend without cease, the living person remains at peace, and disasters and illnesses do not arise. If on that day one purifies body and mind, abstains from wine and lust, wears clean new garments, burns incense, and cultivates goodness, and further, rests briefly, then the hun-souls unite with the po-souls, yin and yang merge, the Dao-qi flourishes within, and the root of life is firmly secured.

If on that day one indulges in wine and lust, confusing and defiling the body, then when the hun-souls return, they remain three paces away from the body, unable to unite. Filth and impurity assail them, and the hun-souls retreat. If this confusion occurs three times, and the hun-souls fail to unite with the po-souls, then yang weakens and yin prevails, and the po-souls seize the opportunity. The po-souls are the transformation of yin and constantly seek to prevent the hun-souls from returning to the body. If the hun-souls do not return, the po-souls commune with yin spirits, and when yin unites with yin, the five ghosts flourish. This gives rise to wandering spirits and manifold evils, causing one to fall into an unrousable sleep, the five senses to become confused, and disasters and illnesses to arise, leading ultimately to death.

When the hun-souls return but cannot unite with the body, they grieve and weep, while the po-souls leap and dance, laughing and singing: 'Return, but there is no union for me; return, but there is no abode for me.' Thus, the five ghosts invade the chamber, and the Three Corpses rage wildly. The Three Ones are not guarded, and the true dwelling becomes empty." The *Central Yellow Scripture* states: "Alas! The twelve towers of the mysterious palace—who would have thought they would become the dwelling of the Three Corpses? How sorrowful!"

On one’s destiny’s birthdate, six times a year, the three hun-souls return to the body six times to subdue the yin po-souls, preventing the incursion of demonic paths. The hundred spirits gather, the hun-souls find peace, the po-souls are rectified, and the myriad qi endure. Free from suffering and affliction, the body radiates light, preserving eternal life. One may ascend as a flying immortal. Moreover, on the day of one’s destiny’s birth, when the myriad spirits descend, during days of purification, one purifies body and mind, burns incense, recites the scripture, recognizes the star lord of their destiny under the Northern Dipper, and offers sincere prayers. Good intentions evoke responses, disasters and transgressions dissolve, and the ten thousand sages and thousand perfected beings all come to guard and protect—thus the Dao of immortality is swiftly attained.

Wherever this scripture resides, the thousand perfected pay reverence, and the ten thousand sages protect and uphold it. Demonic spirits vanish in silence, and malevolent spirits hide away. Worldly disasters and calamities all dissolve. When the scripture is held in the heart, the true sages within the body revere and protect it, so that demons cannot intrude, ghosts and spirits cannot bewitch, and the disasters and calamities of the world all vanish of themselves.

This is called the *Northern Dipper Destiny Prolonging Life Scripture and Its Instructions*, the path of cultivating the true. This scripture requires personal practice—it is the scripture and instructions for prolonging life on one’s destiny’s birthdate, the path of cultivating the true. Attaining the Dao and roaming freely, all depend on this scripture; realizing sagehood and becoming a perfected being, all depend on this scripture; transcending life and death, all depend on this scripture; protecting men and women, all depend on this scripture. Preserving life and prolonging years, all attain freedom. It is an eternal treasure for the body, bringing blessings and longevity. Guard and revere it; do not show it to the unworthy.

This is where the scripture’s personal practice lies: in small measure, it preserves life and prolongs years, increasing blessings and longevity; in great measure, it transcends life and death, attains the Dao and roams freely, realizes sagehood and becomes a perfected being, and endures as a treasure for the body. Guard and revere it; do not show it to the unworthy."

As Lord Lao finished expounding the scripture, dragons and cranes, celestial immortals, came to welcome him back to the Jade Capital. At that time, the Celestial Master, having received the wondrous dharma, spoke these words, vowing to propagate it and transmit it to the virtuous. "If there are men or women who receive, uphold, and recite this scripture, I, together with the ten precept-enforcing immortal officials, shall protect and uphold them wherever they may be."
